revision.comment: [[User:Monkbot/Task 9: Ship infobox lists|Task 9]]: convert line-break list(s) to unordered list(s) in ship infobox templates;

{{Infobox ship characteristics | Hide header = | Header caption = | Ship class = Cargo ship | Ship tonnage =*{{GRT|2,026}} *{{NRT|1,073}}><!--xx,xxx [[deadweight tonnage|DWT]]--> | Ship displacement = | Ship length = {{convert|272|ft|0|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship beam = {{convert|40|ft|0|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship height = | Ship draught = <!--{{convert|xxx|ft|x|in|m|2}}--> | Ship depth = {{convert|17|ft|2|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship decks = | Ship deck clearance = | Ship ramps = | Ship ice class = | Ship range = | Ship power = | Ship propulsion = Triple expansion steam engine | Ship speed = <!--{{convert|xx|kn|km/h}}--> | Ship capacity = | Ship crew = | Ship notes = | Ship complement = | Ship armament = }} |}
'''''Brick Quinto''''' was a {{GRT|2066|link=off}} [[collier (ship type)|collier]] that was built in 1943 as '''''Empire Daughter''''' by [[Grangemouth Dockyard Company|Grangemouth Dockyard Co Ltd]], [[Grangemouth]], [[Stirlingshire]], [[United Kingdom]] for the [[Ministry of War Transport]] (MoWT). In 1946, she was sold into merchant service and renamed '''''Glanrhyd'''''. Further sales in 1948 and 1949 saw her renamed '''''Noeldale''''' and '''''Kinnaird Head''''' respectively. In 1961, she was sold to [[Italy]] and renamed ''Brick Quinto''. She served until 1976, when she was scrapped.
==Description== The ship was built in 1943 by [[Grangemouth Dockyard Company|Grangemouth Dockyard Co Ltd]], [[Grangemouth]], [[Stirlingshire]].<ref name=Ships>{{cite book |last1= Mitchell |first1=W.H. |last2=Sawyer |first2=L.A. |year=1995 |title=The Empire Ships |page=not cited |publisher= Lloyd's of London Press Ltd |location= London, New York, Hamburg, Hong Kong |isbn=1-85044-275-4}}</ref> She was yard number 673.<ref name=Searle>{{cite web |url=http://www.searlecanada.org/sunderland/sunderland034.html#empireday |title=THE SUNDERLAND SITE - PAGE 034, SHIPBUILDERS - PAGE 11 |publisher=Searle |accessdate=1 June 2011}}</ref>
The ship was {{convert|272|ft|0|in|m|2}} long, with a beam of {{convert|40|ft|0|in|m|2}}. She had a depth of {{convert|17|ft|5|in|m|2}}<!-- and a draught of {{convert|xx|ft|x|in|m|2}}--> She was assessed at {{GRT|2,066}}.<ref name=Ships/> {{NRT|1,073}}.<ref name=Daughter43>{{cite web |url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=43b1112.pdf |title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, NAVIRES A VAPEUR ET A MOTEURS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=15 July 2011}}</ref><!-- Her [[deadweight tonnage|DWT]] was x,xxx.<ref name=xxxx/>-->
The ship was propelled by a [[triple expansion steam engine]], which had cylinders of {{convert|17|in|cm}}, {{convert|27|in|cm}} and {{convert|48|in|cm}} diameter by {{convert|36|in|cm}} stroke. The engine was built by North East Marine Engine (1938) Ltd, [[Newcastle upon Tyne]].<ref name=Daughter43/><!-- It drove a screw propeller and could propel the ship at {{convert|xx|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=xxxx/>-->
==History== ''Empire Daughter'' was built for the MoWT.<ref name=Ships/> She was launched on 27 December 1943 and completed in April 1944.<ref name=Ships/> The United Kingdom Official Number 169105 and [[Code Letters]] GCSQ were allocated. Her port of registry was Grangemouth.<ref name=ID>{{cite web |url=http://convoyweb.org.uk/signal/index.html?search_all.php~signalmain |title=Signal Letters Database |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=4 June 2011}} (Enter GCSQ or Empire Daughter in relevant search box)</ref> She was placed under the management of [[Stephenson Clarke Shipping|Stephenson, Clarke and Associated Companies Ltd]].<ref name=Daughter43/>
''Empire Daughter'' was a member of a number of convoys during [[World War II]]. She was a member of Convoy FS 1584, which departed from [[Methil]], [[Fife]] on 23 September 1944 and arrived at [[Southend-on-Sea|Southend]], [[Essex]] on 25 September. She was also a member of Convoy TAM 124, which departed from Southend on 31 March 1945 and arrived at [[Antwerp]], [[Belgium]] on 1 April; Convoy ATM 135, which departed from Antwerp on 25 April and arrived at Southend on 26 April; and Convoy TAM 171, which departed from Southend on 17 May and arrived at Antwerp that day.<ref name=Port>{{cite web |url=http://convoyweb.org.uk/ports/index.html?search.php?vessel=EMPIRE%20DAUGHTER~armain |title=EMPIRE DAUGHTER |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=4 June 2011}}</ref>
In 1946, ''Empire Daughter'' was sold to Harries Brothers & Co Ltd, [[Swansea]], [[Glamorgan]] and was renamed ''Glanrhyd''. In 1948, ''Glanrhyd'' was sold to Tavistock Shipping Co Ltd, [[London]] and renamed ''Noeldale''. In 1949, ''Noeldale'' was sold to Henry & Mc Gregor Ltd, [[Leith]], [[Scotland]] and renamed ''Kinnaird Head''. In 1961, ''Kinnaird Head'' was sold to Gino Gardella, [[Italy]] and was renamed ''Brick Quinto''. She served until 1976, when she was scrapped at [[Savona]], Italy.<ref name=Ships/>
